captions.text: I am going to talk to you tonight
about coming out of the closet.
And not in the traditional sense,
I think we all have closets,
your closet may be telling someone
you love her for the first time.
Or telling someone you have cancer.
Or any of the other hard conversations

All the closet is, 
is a hard conversation.

And although our topics 
may vary tremendously,

the experience of being in 
and coming out of the closet
It is scary, and we hate it,
and it needs to be done.

Several years ago, I was working 
at the Southside Walnut Café,

I would go through phases 
of militant, lesbian, intensity.
quoting Ani DiFranco lyrics as gospel,

and depending on the bagginess 
of my cargo shorts,
and how recently I'd shaved my head,

the question would often 
be sprung on me,

"Mmmm, are you a boy, 
or are you a girl?"

And there would be 
an awkward silence at the table,
I'd clench my jaw a little tighter,

hold my coffee pot 
with a little more vengeance,

the Dad would awkwardly 
shuffle his newspaper,

and the Mom would shoot 
a chilling stare at her kid.
And it got to the point that everytime
I walked up to a table that had a kid
And that is a terrible feeling.

So I promised myself 
that the next time,
I would have that hard conversation.

So within a matter of weeks, 
it happens again:
"Are you a boy, or are you a girl?"
But this time, I am ready.

And I am about to go 
all Woman Studies 101 on this table.
I've got my Betty Friedan quotes,
I've got my Gloria Steinem quotes,

I even got this little bit from
Vagina Monologues I'm gonna do,

so I take a deep breath, 
and I look down,
is a 4-year old girl in a pink dress.
Not a challenge to a feminist duel,
just a kid, with a question:
"Are you a boy, or are you a girl?"
So I take another deep breath,
squat down next to her and say:
"Hey, I know it's kind of confusing,
my hair is short like a boy's,

and you know how sometimes 
you like to wear a pink dress,

and sometimes you like 
to wear your comfie jammies,

well, I'm more of 
a comfie jammies kind of a girl."
And this kid looks me dead in the eye
without missing a beat and says:
with fish, can I get a pancake please?"

"Oh, OK, you're a girl. 
How 'bout that pancake?"

It was the easiest hard conversation 
I have ever had.
we were both real with each other.
I've lived in a few closets in my life,

and yeah, most often, 
my walls happen to be rainbow.
you can't tell what color the walls are.
You just know what it feels like

So really, my closet 
is no different than yours,
Sure, I can give you 100 reasons
why coming out of my closet
was harder than coming out of yours,
when you just cheated on them.
is harder than telling your 5-year old
We need to stop ranking our "hard"

to make us feel better 
or worse about our closet
and just commiserate on the fact
At some point in our lives,
Or at least, safer than what lies
on the other side of that door.
But I'm here to tell you,
no matter what your walls are made of,

a closet is no place 
for a person to live.
So why is coming out of any closet,
We're so concerned about the reaction
of the other person, and understandably.

So let's kick out 
on stress for a minute.

Stress is a natural reaction
in your body.
When you encounter a perceived threat,
And this is a totally normal reaction.

when that threat was 
being chased by a wooly mammoth.

if you're being chased 
by a wooly mammoth,
or if your computer just crashed,

or if your in-laws just showed up 
on your doorsteps,

or if you're about 
to jump out of a plane,
or if you need to tell someone you love
that you have a brain tumor.

the wooly mammoth 
chases you for, what,
that can go on for years,
and your body just can't handle that.
Chronic exposure to adrenaline and cortisol
disrupts almost every system in your body
When you do not have hard conversations,
when you keep the truth about yourself a secret,
I was not the militant lesbian

ready to fight any 4-year old 
that walked into the café.
I had spent my entire life
trying to not disappoint these people.

And now, I was turning 
the world upside down.
I was burning the pages of the script
we had all followed for so long,
but if you do not throw that grenade,
One of my most memorable grenade-tosses

It was the first time 
that many on attendance
So in doing my Maid of Honor duties,
in my black dress and heels,

and finally landed at the table 
of my parents' friends,
folks that had known me for years.
And after a little small talk,
one of the women shouted out:
And the battle of gay relatebility
"Ash, have you ever been to the Castro?"

"Well, yeah, actually, 
we have friends in San Francisco."
"Ash, do you know my hairdresser Antonio,

he's really good, and 
he's never talked about a girlfriend."

Our favorite TV show: 
favorite, Will and Grace,
you know who we love? Jack.

but wanting so desperately
to show her support,
to let me know she was on my side,

"Well, sometimes my husband 
wears pink shirts."
And I had a choice in that moment,
I could go back to my girlfriend,
and their inability to jump through
and realize that that was maybe

one of the hardest things 
that they had ever done.
was them coming out of their closets.
Sure, it would have been easy
to point out where they fell short.
to meet them where they are,
and what else can you ask someone to do,
If you're going to be real with someone,

So, hard conversations 
are still not my strong suit.
And I follow what I like to call
what it takes to come out of any closet,
take the armor off, be yourself.
but I was ready for battle.
If you want someone to be real with you,
they need to know that you bleed too.
You say it, rip the bandaid off.
If you know you are gay,

If you tell your parents 
you might be gay,

they will hold that hope 
that this will change.

And some folks might 
have gotten hurt along the way.
But never apologize for who you are.

And yeah, some folks
may be disappointed.

Those are their expectations 
of who you are,
is the one that you want to write.
So the next time you find yourself
know that we've all been there before.
And you may feel so very alone,
but we need you out here,
no matter what your walls are made of.

there are others 
peering through the keyhole
looking for the next brave soul

and show the world that 
we are bigger than our closets,
and that a closet is no place
for a person to truly live.
Thank you Boulder, enjoy your night.

title: Coming out of your closet | Ash Beckham | TEDxBoulder

comments.text:
Here is what I get when I tell people that I'm gay (Been out of closet 
since I was 16): "I know a girl from church who is gay.. she is nice"  
"Ellen Degeneres is so cool" "You don't *look* gay" "You're too pretty to 
be gay " "Oh wow. I think I might be gay too, how do you know if you are?"  
lol Completely awkward sometimes and random responses. I know they feel 
obligated to say something and think they are trying to be nice, so I let 
it go. One day I feel as though it will be as normal as telling people you 
are Catholic or vegetarian. Coming soon to a mind-set near you!﻿

comments.text:
New age pandering galore here,no doubt.   Some redefining of the term 
homophobia certainly welcome.  The gay agenda isn't just for Ash Beckham 
and about not aplogizing for who you are. In this victimhood mindset, the 
desire to redress the ills carried out against gay folk fuels an semingly 
endless pursuit for acceptance, tolerance, understanding. Yeh - that's what 
we all want, regardless of wether you're  a blokey woman,  a girly man, or 
a more balanced individual.   Why distinguish this so called homophobia 
from bullying ?  Why believe your suffering to be special because of your 
abnormal orientation ?     Just imagine if Putin's Russia was pro gay - I'm 
sure the liberal left would be up in arms about the American and EU 
shenanigans in Ukraine.  Nah - those Ruskis are just behind the 
times........... Superpowers on the brink and the activists want to make 
sure everyone loves gay people.  Nothing it seems is more important than 
ones imagined identity ???      Get over it, most peole are not gay and 
most people who are not gay, neither attack nor bully gays.
Priorities darlings. Mine is to make sure the needless propaganda doesn't 
truly screw up the youths.... ooops too late. 
I am witness to that screwing up of the youth - I have seen weak parents 
bow to the pressures of political correctness and in so doing allow their 
children to play with notions about life that have confused the hell out of 
them.   I wonder what disproportionate amount of counsellors/psychiatrists 
are gay?  Yeh - fancy words and ideaology can really get out of control.    
Humans forever - yay.      ﻿

comments.author: healingtv

comments.text:
Parenting Skills - www.akashicreading.com

So many of the people I work with, both students and clients, suffer from 
having difficult childhoods. This ranges anywhere from distant and 
non-demonstrative parents or families where the person just never fit in to 
literal torture. And before anyone starts that story in their head that 
there is some scale of hard where these people fit in, take a listen to Ash 
Beckham. Nobody's hard is any more or less than anyone else's. Hard is just 
hard.

So our childhood's where hard. So what? you say. Just get on with it. Move 
on with your life. Well, to that I say "No." Why should we? Oh, I don't 
mean digging in to figure out why or blaming this that or the other for the 
way we are now. That has its place, it's time, and it's healing modalities. 
I'm talking about the little wounded kids we still are inside who don't 
need one more lesson in how to survive. They need to be cuddled and loved 
and hugged up and reminded that they are precious just because they exist. 
Just because we're adult doesn't mean we don't still need good parents and 
good parenting. That need doesn't go away because we go out into the world 
on our own.

The hard part is that we continue looking for others to provide it to us. 
Our lovers, our friends, our coworkers and even acquaintances. Every 
situation we get into becomes a means to get some form of love and 
nurturing and bonding and support and enough is never enough. So we wander 
through life searching, never finding, moving through one relationship 
after another and never getting what we need. So let's stop the cycle. 
Since we are adults, we know exactly what we need and how we need it (in 
fact we've related it to all of our lovers in detail so we have it 
memorized) how about we start providing it to the one person who needs it 
the most...us. All the energy and effort that we put into everything else 
everywhere else, let's direct a little or a lot our way. Move beyond 
self-care to parenting and see yourself as the precious piece of divinity 
you are. Use your parenting skills where they are most deserved and let the 
world spin on without you for a few moments. It will get along just fine...﻿

comments.text:
The pioneers of homosexual activism emerged in Germany in the 1860s.
Men like Ulrichs, and Kertbeny.
Strangely enough, though the homosexual was ostentatiously portrayed as 
morally corrupt, sick,  criminal and borderline insane by the first public 
homosexuals THEMSELVES,
it was at the same time energetically and even vehemently argued how unjust 
and sad it was, 
that this unfortunate, suffering creature should have to suffer even more 
than he already did, 
and be oppressed by law, 
being criminally penalized and not granted the same rights as anybody else.

Indeed, 150 years ago, 
when homosexuality first became a fascinating and scandalous topic of 
social interest, 
a mediatized issue,
ALREADY then, this was the discourse...

It makes you wonder if much has really changed in a century and a half...

Yes, some things did change very significantly:
authority has since some decades decriminalized homosexuality, 
and most shrinks no longer contend homosexuals are mentally ill per se.
But that's basically it.

In terms of perception, what people REALLY feel deep down about homosexuals,
not all that much has changed at all.

Today the story goes that there's so much "hate "and "homophobia" around,
and vocal, mass-mediatized gays keep asserting that these are highly 
alarming, 
strange, irrational phenomena,
that are the very reason they are  'fighting', and that all of society must 
be
mobilized against these inhumane forces of darkness.

Gays have 'come a long way', but the fight isn't over by a long shot.
There is still so much hate to tackle!!

Gay activists really have no other message, 
and it seems this incessant and monolithic focus on the oppressive, evil 
forces
of "hate" and "homophobia" and "bigotry",
that quite apparently are not at all abating but rather increasing,
invariably seems to yield counter-productive results.

It seems there is something self-defeating about this 'War on Homophobia',
something that doesn't quite square,
and that is strangely reminiscent of the 'War on Drugs' or the 'War on 
Terror',
as if the very purpose and the effect of such "wars" was precisely to create
what it claims to combat.


The very discourse of vocal gays today shows that public perception of 
homosexuality is STILL extremely negative, and one has to wonder:
who has created this perception, if not especially the vocal gays 
themselves, 
the gays people have seen on their television screens?

Could they at least be partly responsible for all this negativity, this 
'hate'?

In fact, it is a true headbreaker to try thinking of anything positive gays 
have
put out in the public sphere that has ever generated positive associations 
with 
homosexuality.
 I have to admit I can't think of anything, except some vapid lines, like
'Gay is Good', or 'Proud To Be Gay'.

Such hazy propaganda slogans, lines chanted by parading gays,
only tend confirm that actual positive content is indeed  lacking 
altogether, 
or there would be no place for such trite rhetoric.

The negative content on the other hand is simply overwhelming, and all over 
the place.

For one thing, it is simply a fact of life that from the mid-eighties to 
the mid-nineties, 
everybody has seen the sick gays on their televions screens, 
walking corpses soon dying of mysterious afflictions...
Enough to make anyone quite 'phobic'.

People have seen many obscene and pornographic gays in organized parades,
obsessed with c*ck and promiscuous sex,
and flaunting it all at the public,
as if obscenity and sexual indugence where amazing acts of empowering 
gayness.

Everybody has seen many effeminate gays, walking with a wish, talking with 
a lisp,
whose main pupose in life appears to be getting stuffed with c*ck,
and who don't appear to know much else.

What's more, a link between homosexuality and paedophilia has 
systematically 
been introduced into the collective sphere since many decades, 
by many gay activists who condoned this practice,
and who typically will argue in a suspect fashion for the further lowering 
of the age of consent, 
bringing up such creepy arguments as 'children's right to love'.

"Founding father" of modern gaylib Harry Hay for instance is but one of many
 famous gay activists who were in  touch with NAMBLA, 
the North American Man Boy Love Association. 

Hay went as far as to publicly support Nambla while parading in a Gay Pride 
on the streets,
thus effectively mediatizing a link between gays and paedophiles.
 Pictures of this are easily found on the internet.

It is important to elaborate some more on this paedo association
and link, and before doing so, let me explain why;

I am not a religious bigot trying to discredit gays and vociferating that
they are paedophiles.
I know very well that the 'archetypical' gay man,
the  ' gay bottom',
dreams of REAL MEN, grown, mature virile men NOT of children.

It is however an unfortunate fact of life that many of the leaders of gay
activism appear to have had little qualms about paedophilia,
or associating with paedophiles, either tacitly or explicitly condoning it  
or worse,  engaging in it themselves.

It is crucial to make the distinction between true paedophilia, and
attraction to underage but sexually mature boys;
it is generally agreed that the range of paedophile interest extends to
children up to age 13 at the most. They must be prepubescent.

While such actual, fullblown paedophilia with sexually unmatured kids
has without a doubt been rare among gay activists,
many instances can be found of sexual relations with adolescents.
(Even Harvey Milk for instance, Hirshfeld, but really too many to mention).

The link between gay activism and fullblown paedophiles however DOES
exist, through people like Vern Bullough, 
publisher of Paidika and activist for Nambla, and through Alfred Kinsey 
whose criminal work with paedophiles is
not only well-documented today, but openly admitted in his landmark
book on Male Sexuality.

Not only were extensive paedophile experiments on toddlers as young
as 6 months old reported in tables in the pages of Kinsey's work,
there are also explicit passages such as the following:

'Better data on preadolescent climax come from the histories of adult males
who have had sexual contacts with younger boys and who, with their adult
backgrounds, are able to recognize and interpret the boys’ experiences.
Unfortunately, not all of the subjects with such contacts in their histories
were questioned on this point of preadolescent reactions; but 9 of our adult
male subjects have observed such orgasm. Some of these adults are
technically trained persons who have kept diaries or other records, which
have been put at our disposal; and from them we have secured information
on 317 preadolescents who were either observed in self-masturbation, or
who were observed in contacts with other boys or older adults.2
Kinsey, et al, Sexual Behavior of the Human Male, 1948"

It is therefore important to realize that if today many people resent
gays on the basis of the dark spectre of child molestation,
they aren't being irrationally 'phobic' and 'hateful':
this link simply DOES EXIST, and has been put out by gay activists
THEMSELVES.

Until significant numbers of gays cleanse this Paedophile Smear by
exposing and rejecting the people who have usurped their positions
as spokesmen for all gays, they will carry that smear themselves,
and NOT because of straight bigotry, or some 'irrational phobia'...﻿

comments.author: Koray Sercan Kuru

comments.text:
What people often forget, conveniently sometimes, is that the 'human 
condition' is universal.

Everyone has something.  Something that hurts, something that helps, 
something that raises up, something that beats down, and the deep abiding 
fear that there is something wrong with them that everyone will hate them 
for when it comes to light.

We feel as if we are in a leaking boat, adrift in a vast sea, and no one is 
looking for us.  When in fact we are all bobbing around in the water, 
within arms reach of each other, and no where near alone on a planet with 8 
billion people on it.﻿
comments.author: Bikalpa Kattel

comments.text: Very true
comments.author: Marie Diamandis

comments.text:
I can fully identify with what this woman is saying because I've been there 
and done that and I'm lucky I don't have any scars because of it.  She is 
right we all have our own closets.  

A good friend one time asked me whats the difference between being in a 
rut, in a closet and in a grave?  I didn't have an answer for him.  His 
answer floored me "Nothing, they are all the same the only things that 
changes is the size."  It took me a while to grasp what he had said... now 
it's your turn.  Blessings all, be well and be safe﻿
